channel.title: Comments on: What is deferred name resolution and why do you need to care?
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: traingamer
item.dc:creator: traingamer
item.description: I got here from your forum post and I completely missed your CREATE table #temptable example in your second block. My last comment is silly as a result (especially since SELECT...INTO always creates a table). Sorry about that.<br /> <br />
item.content:encoded: I got here from your forum post and I completely missed your CREATE table #temptable example in your second block. My last comment is silly as a result (especially since SELECT…INTO always creates a table). Sorry about that.

item.title: By: Erik
item.dc:creator: Erik
item.content:encoded:
Or if you want, the poor man’s create table is SELECT INTO WHERE 1 = 0

You just have to specify some columns that are the correct data types.

Now you can INSERT to your heart’s content.

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.content:encoded:
traingamer , you can only create the temp table once in the batch of code

Here is another thing for you to ponder ðŸ™‚

DECLARE @x INT

SET @x = 0

CREATE TABLE #temptable (VALUE INT identity)
IF (@x = 0)
BEGIN
ALTER TABLE #temptable ADD Col2 varchar(40) default ‘bla’
INSERT #temptable DEFAULT VALUES

END
ELSE
BEGIN
ALTER TABLE #temptable ADD Col2 int default 3
INSERT #temptable DEFAULT VALUES
END

SELECT * FROM #temptable

DROP TABLE #temptable

item.title: By: traingamer
item.dc:creator: traingamer
item.description: OK, so if you declare @i only once outside of the IF, that will fix the second example, but what about the temptable? Do you have to specifically create a temptable before the SELECT .. INTO... to make it work?
item.content:encoded: OK, so if you declare @i only once outside of the IF, that will fix the second example, but what about the temptable? Do you have to specifically create a temptable before the SELECT .. INTO… to make it work?
